Package org.openpnp.util

Class Collect

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.openpnp.util.Collect
  • public class Collect
extends java.lang.Object
    Some basic Collection utilities. Called Collect instead of something like Collections to avoid namespace collisions with java.utils.Collections.

      • cartesianProduct

        public static <T> java.util.List<java.util.List<T>> cartesianProduct​(java.util.List<java.util.List<T>> lists)
        Create the cartesian product of a list of lists. The results will contain every possible distinct combination of the elements of the input lists. Example: cartesianProduct(Arrays.asList(Arrays.asList("A", "B"), Arrays.asList("1", "2"))) [[A, 1], [A, 2], [B, 1], [B, 2]] This method specifically allows for nulls in the input elements. Multiple nulls will be counted multiple times.
        Parameters:
        lists -
        Returns:

      • allCombinationsOfSize

        public static <T> java.util.List<java.util.List<T>> allCombinationsOfSize​(java.util.List<T> list,
                                                                          int number)
        Generate all combinations with the specified number of the elements taken from the given list. For example, all combinations of 3 elements taken from [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] yields: [[1, 2, 3], [1, 2, 4], [1, 2, 5], [1, 3, 4], [1, 3, 5], [1, 4, 5], [2, 3, 4], [2, 3, 5], [2, 4, 5], [3, 4, 5]]. The relative ordering of the elements in each combination is the same as they appeared in the original list.
        Parameters:
        list - - the list of elements whose combinations are to be formed
        number - - the number of elements in each combination
        Returns:
        - the list of combinations or an empty list if number > list.size()

      • extractSublist

        public static <T> java.util.List<T> extractSublist​(java.util.List<T> list,
                                                   int... indices)
        Extracts a sublist of elements from a list
        Parameters:
        list - - the list of elements
        indices - - the indices of the elements to extract
        Returns:
        the sublist of elements with the elements in the same order as indices

      • computeInPlaceUpdateIndices

        public static <T> void computeInPlaceUpdateIndices​(java.util.List<T> listToModify,
                                                   java.util.List<T> targetList,
                                                   java.util.List<int[]> indicesToRemove,
                                                   java.util.List<int[]> indicesToInsert)
        Computes a list of index ranges to remove and a list of index ranges to insert that updates one list to match another list without disturbing the elements that are common to both lists. Useful for updating combo boxes and tables when items are inserted or removed without disturbing the currently selected item. 
         As an example, suppose:
      listToUpdate = [3, 5, 7, 8, 10, 11, 12, 17, 18, 20, 21, 26, 33, 36]
      targetList = [2, 5, 9, 11, 14, 17, 22, 23, 24, 27, 28, 31, 32, 37, 38]
      
      Running this method results in:
      indicesToRemove = [ [13, 8], [6, 6], [4, 2], [0, 0] ]
      indicesToInsert = [ [0, 0], [2, 2], [4, 4], [6, 14] ]
      
      The removals need to be performed first and in the order specified in indicesToRemove:
      Removing elements 13 down to 9 results in listToUpdate = [3, 5, 7, 8, 10, 11, 12, 17],
      removing element 6 results in listToUpdate = [3, 5, 7, 8, 10, 11, 17],
      removing elements 4 down to 2 results in listToUpdate = [3, 5, 11, 17],
      and finally removing element 0 results in listToUpdate = [5, 11, 17].
      
      Next, the insertions need to be performed and in the order specified in indicesToInsert:
      Inserting element 0 (2) results in listToUpdate = [2, 5, 11, 17],
      inserting element 2 (9) results in listToUpdate = [2, 5, 9, 11, 17],
      inserting element 4 (14) results in listToUpdate = [2, 5, 9, 11, 14, 17],
      and finally inserting elements 6 to 14 (22, 23, 24, 27, 28, 31, 32, 37, 38) results in 
      listToUpdate = [2, 5, 9, 11, 14, 17, 22, 23, 24, 27, 28, 31, 32, 37, 38].
      
      Note, listToUpdate now contains exactly the same elements as newList and that the 
      elements that we already in both lists (5, 11, and 17) were not touched.
        Parameters:
        listToModify - - the list that is to be updated. Must contain unique items and must be sorted in the same order as targetList.
        targetList - - the list that listToModify is to be updated to match. Must contain unique items and must be sorted in the same order as listToModify.
        indicesToRemove - - a list of index ranges that are to be removed from listToModify. Each entry in this list is a two element array of indices [a, b] where a >= b. All elements in the range a down to b (inclusive) should be removed from the listToModify. The list of index ranges is sorted highest to lowest so that the removals can be performed in the order specified (descending) without risk of causing changes to the indices of elements that are yet to be removed. Note that all removals must to be performed in the order specified (descending) and before any insertions specified by indicesToInsert.
        indicesToInsert - - a list of index ranges that are of the elements in targetList that are to be inserted into listToModify. Each entry of this list is a two element array of indices [a, b] where a <= b. All elements in the range a to b (inclusive) need to be copied from the targetList and inserted into the listToModify. The list of index ranges is sorted lowest to highest so that the insertion point in listToModify is the same as the index of the item in targetList. Note that all insertions must be performed in the order specified (ascending) and only after all removals specified by indicesToRemove.
